docs.lead_paragraph: Carrie Young's daughter came into the world 10 months after New Jersey's revamped welfare plan was enacted. Had she been born on her due date in late July, her mother might have received $64 more a month. As it was, Ms. Young's family has become one of 470 on welfare that have grown in size but not in income since the state's get-tough policy went into effect on Aug. 1. Her daughter was born on Aug. 5, one of the first babies affected by a a provision that denies additional cash benefits to mothers who have children while on welfare.

headline.main: New Jersey Welfare's Give and Take; Mothers Get College Aid, but No Extra Cash for Newborns

docs.snippet: Carrie Young's daughter came into the world 10 months after New Jersey's revamped welfare plan was enacted. Had she been born on her due date in late July, her mother might have received $64 more a month.   As it was, Ms. Young's family has become...

docs.lead_paragraph: As concern about breast cancer continues to rise, mammography has become a booming business in this country. But some of the business has been too good, studies have shown, leading to an overabundance of clinics, high prices and poor x-rays. Last week the Food and Drug Administration, under pressure from Senator Barbara Mikulski, Democrat of Maryland, announced stricter standards on breast x-rays. The new rules require that the country's 12,000 clinics pass inspection and be accredited, use up-to-date equipment and trained technicians, keep complete records and undergo annual audits. The rules take effect Oct. 1, 1994, but clinics are expected to start upgrading now.

headline.main: NOV. 28-DEC. 4: New Rules on Breast X-Rays; F.D.A. Raises Standard For Mammography Clinics
